reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central pillar of the paper’s headline conclusion (“most plausible moral views are fussy”): the Section 3 formal framework (VNM-representable, cardinal, resource-scaling taxonomy) and the move from results inside that framework to a broad claim about moral philosophy. If that generalization fails, the paper’s strongest cross-theory support for ‘no easy eutopia’ is weakened, though Section 2’s informal ‘fragility’ considerations would still stand, so centrality isn’t 1. The critique has moderate refutational force: it plausibly shows the paper’s conclusion should be conditional on a narrower class of theories and that some key claims (e.g., about separability/linearity and what boundedness implies “in practice”) are under-argued; however, it does not demonstrate that the excluded theories are actually easygoing (only that they don’t fit neatly), so it only partially undermines the substantive conclusion. Most of the critique’s points are correct and well-aimed (cardinal/VNM assumptions exclude many views; boundedness-to-linearity depends on what’s being bounded/concave in; separability claims are contestable), and it is clear and focused with little fluff.
title: Narrow formal framework may generate fussiness as a modeling artifact
